Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Opportunities in Molecular Biology at Ohio State University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to the Ohio State University, located in Columbus, OH, will support the training of 10 students for 9 weeks during each of the summers of 2016- 2019. This program provides research experience in the broad area of Molecular Biology (including fields such as cell biology, genetics, biochemistry and biophysics), with specific research opportunities chosen to match students' own interest and experience. Scientific mentors from the departments of Molecular Genetics, Chemistry and Biochemistry, and Microbiology are internationally recognized scientists with strong interests in mentoring research-oriented undergraduates and facilitating success in their future research careers. The cornerstone of the program is the individual research experience, with student participants engaging in individually mentored projects that utilize model organisms to address fundamental scientific questions. Students also take part in professional development activities designed to enable future research success, including training in ethics, scientific communication, and writing skills. Group social activities highlighting Columbus attractions enhance the collegial and supportive atmosphere of the program.

It is anticipated that a total of 40 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will participate in the training program. Participants are selected by the PI and co-PI, with a focus on inclusion of students with limited research opportunities and students from groups underrepresented in the sciences. The program has a demonstrated record of success, with the majority of past participants continuing in science careers.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to ascertain student career paths and effects of the REU program on their career progression. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program, including application materials, is available by visiting https://molgen.osu.edu/research-experience-undergraduates, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Cole at cole.354@osu.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Jackman at jackman.14@osu.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central goals of the REU program are to increase the diversity, number, and quality of future scientists. The future of scientific research hinges on the strength of graduate education, and given the changing demographics of the US population, it become more critical to foster the development of a pool of excellent young scientists who represent the current US population. The REU Site In Molecular Biology seeks to:

  • provide opportunities for students from historically under-represented groups in science
  • provide experiences for students from institutions with limited research opportunities
  • strengthen the credentials of students with average academic records to enhance their potential
  • increase opportunities for students with already strong academic records  

 

We provided summer research experiences for 47 students between 2016 and 2019. These students spent 9 weeks on the Ohio State University campus, conducting independent research in a mentor laboratory. They also took part in research training, ethics training, networking opportunities and professional development activities designed to promote and nurture their commitment to scientific research, and build connections with the scientific community. 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT:

Students taking part in the program contribute to ongoing research in host labs. The research programs use model organisms to address fundamental questions in biology, ranging from tRNA metabolism to vertebrate development to plant cellular biology among others. In addition, through their engagement in writing programs and presentation of a final poster, students will become stronger communicators with a deeper understanding of science. Although it is difficult for a student to complete a body of work in a 9-week summer internship that is sufficient for publication, we have requested that mentors make every effort to design self-contained projects that provide outstanding training while allowing the participant the possibility to generate data for a figure that will appear in a publication. This strategy has led to inclusion of an REU participant as a co-author on several papers published by OSU mentors to date, as well as many papers in preparation from more recent years. As students enter graduate school and continue their education, we anticipate that they will contribute to diverse research programs outside of Ohio State.

BROADER IMPACTS

This program had wide broader impacts, mostly related to "advancing discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning" and "broadening participation of under-represented groups". The program provided undergraduate research training for groups under-represented in science, and for students with limited research opportunities. 76% of our participants came from groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. Our data from program assessments demonstrate that the REU experience positively influenced students to pursue graduate education and research careers, and indeed many students have entered a graduate program after graduation from college, and thus we expect that the majority of these students will continue into graduate education, and many will make important contributions to scientific knowledge.
